name: Manhattan
instructions: Stir ingredients with ice, strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with a cherry.
notes: A timeless classic. Use a bold rye whiskey and good vermouth for balance.

name: Old Fashioned
instructions: Muddle sugar and bitters with water, add bourbon, stir with ice, and garnish with orange twist.
notes: Simple, smooth, and spirit-forward. The benchmark for whiskey cocktails.

name: Sazerac
instructions: Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe. Muddle sugar and bitters, add whiskey, stir with ice, and strain into the prepared glass.
notes: A New Orleans classic—aromatic, potent, and rich in history.

name: Dry Martini
instructions: Stir ingredients with ice, strain into a chilled martini glass, and garnish with a lemon twist or olive.
notes: Elegant and crisp. Adjust vermouth ratio to taste—less for drier, more for balance.

name: Pisco Sour
instructions: Shake all ingredients without ice, then shake again with ice. Strain into a coupe glass and garnish with Angostura bitters.
notes: Silky and tart with a light foam cap. A South American favorite.

name: Paper Plane
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe glass.
notes: Modern and balanced—equal parts sweet, bitter, and sour perfection.

name: Cosmopolitan
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a lime twist.
notes: Bright, tart, and sophisticated. The ultimate 90s revival done right.

name: Aperol Spritz
instructions: Combine prosecco and Aperol in a glass with ice. Top with soda water and garnish with an orange slice.
notes: Light and refreshing. Perfect for warm afternoons or brunch.

name: Perfect Manhattan
instructions: Stir ingredients with ice, strain into a chilled coupe glass, and garnish with a cherry or lemon twist.
notes: A refined Manhattan with half sweet and half dry vermouth—balanced and nuanced.

name: Margarita
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a salt-rimmed margarita glass.
notes: Bright and zesty. Balance your lime and sweetness for a perfect sip.

name: Lion’s Tail
instructions: Shake ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a lime twist.
notes: A hidden gem—spicy and rich with warm baking spice notes.

name: Gold Rush
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
notes: Smooth, simple, and bright. A modern whiskey classic.

name: Brown Derby
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe glass.
notes: Light and citrusy with honey sweetness—balanced and refreshing.

name: Whiskey Sour
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice (dry shake first if using egg white). Strain into a rocks glass over ice and garnish with a cherry or orange slice.
notes: A perfect mix of tart and sweet. Add egg white for extra smoothness.

name: Bee’s Knees
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice until well-chilled, then strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
notes: A Prohibition-era classic: floral gin meets bright lemon and smooth honey for a crisp, sweet-tart sip.

name: Boulevardier
instructions: Stir whiskey (or bourbon), Campari and sweet vermouth with ice until well chilled. Strain into a chilled rocks glass (or coupé) and garnish with an orange twist.
notes: A rich & bittersweet variation of the Negroni—warm from whiskey, sharp from Campari, balanced by sweet vermouth.

name: Clover Club
instructions: Add gin, lemon juice, raspberry syrup and egg white into a shaker with ice; shake vigorously until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with 3 raspberries.
notes: A pre-Prohibition classic from Philadelphia—floral gin, tart lemon, sweet raspberry and silky foam from the egg white.

name: Negroni
instructions: Stir gin, Campari and sweet vermouth with ice until well-chilled, then strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with an orange peel.
notes: A true classic built on equal parts — bold, bittersweet and deceptively simple. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

name: Black Manhattan
instructions: Stir rye whiskey, Averna amaro, and both bitters with ice until chilled, then strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass. Garnish with a brandied cherry or orange peel.
notes: A modern Manhattan riff — swapping out sweet vermouth for amaro to deepen the flavor profile. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

name: French 75
ingredients: 3 oz Champagne (or other dry sparkling wine)
instructions: Shake gin, lemon juice and simple syrup with ice, strain into a Champagne flute (or coupe) and top with sparkling wine. Garnish with a lemon twist.
notes: Effervescent and elegant — a fizzy, celebratory classic combining gin, lemon and bubbly. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

name: Rob Roy
instructions: Stir Scotch whisky, sweet vermouth and bitters with ice until well-chilled, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a brandied cherry or lemon twist.
notes: A Manhattan-style cocktail switched to Scotch — rich, refined and rooted in 19th-century bar history. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

name: Old Pal
instructions: Stir rye whiskey, Campari and dry vermouth with ice until well-chilled, then strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.
notes: A sharper, dryer variation on the Negroni/Boulevardier theme — equal parts rye, Campari and dry vermouth. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

name: Americano
instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice, pour in Campari and sweet vermouth, top with chilled soda water and stir gently. Garnish with an orange twist.
notes: Bitter-sweet and bubbly — a lighter aperitif cocktail built from Campari and vermouth then topped with soda. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

name: Whiskey Highball
instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice, pour in whiskey, top with soda water, stir gently, and optionally garnish with a lemon wedge.
notes: Minimalist and refreshing — whiskey and soda combine for a clean, effervescent serve. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

name: White Lady
ingredients: ½ oz orange liqueur (or triple sec)
instructions: Add gin, orange liqueur, lemon juice and egg white into a shaker and dry-shake without ice; then add ice and shake again until well chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with a lemon twist.
notes: A 1920s classic — gin meets citrus and orange liqueur, smoothed out by the egg white. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

name: Between the Sheets
instructions: Add cognac, light rum, triple sec and lemon juice into a shaker with ice; shake until chilled and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a flamed orange peel if desired.
notes: A bold Prohibition-era variation on the Sidecar — equal parts base spirits and orange liqueur, with a splash of lemon. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

name: Sidecar
ingredients: ¾ oz orange liqueur (such as Cointreau)
instructions: Coat the rim of a chilled cocktail glass with sugar (optional). Add ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake until well chilled, strain into the prepared glass, and garnish with an orange twist.
notes: A classic cocktail likely born around World War I — cognac, citrus and orange liqueur in a crisp, tart serve. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

name: Dark and Stormy
instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice, pour in the rum, top with ginger beer, stir gently and optionally add lime juice. Garnish with a lime wedge.
notes: Refreshing and spicy — dark rum meets ginger beer in a classic long drink. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/dark-n-stormy/) )

name: High Five
ingredients: ½ oz Aperol (or bittersweet orange-red aperitivo)
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with the eponymous ‘high five’.
notes: Bright, citrusy and a little bitter — a modern cocktail with a playful twist. (see Difford’s/other sources)

name: Mojito
instructions: Lightly muddle mint leaves with simple syrup and lime juice in a highball glass, add ice and rum, stir, top with soda water, and gently stir again. Garnish with a mint sprig and lime wheel.
notes: Mint, lime, sugar and rum — the Cuban classic that’s crisp, refreshing and timeless. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/mojito/) )

name: Mai Tai
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice and strain (un-strained if using crushed ice) into a double old-fashioned glass with crushed ice. Garnish with a spent lime shell and a mint sprig.
notes: The tiki-classic rum concoction — nutty orgeat, citrus and quality rum deliver the authentic Mai Tai experience. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/traditional-mai-tai/) )

name: Tom Collins
instructions: Combine gin, lemon juice and simple syrup in a highball glass with ice, stir, then top with club soda and garnish with a lemon wheel (and optionally a cherry).
notes: A tall, refreshing Collins-style cocktail—gin, citrus, sugar and fizz. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

name: Last Word
instructions: Pour all ingredients into a shaker with ice, shake until well-chilled, and strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish (optional) with a cherry or lime twist.
notes: A revival classic of equal-parts gin, Chartreuse, maraschino and lime—herbal, tart and perfectly balanced. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

name: Hot Toddy
ingredients: 2 tsp demerara sugar or brown sugar
instructions: Warm a mug with boiling water, discard the water, then add the sugar and cloves and fill about halfway with fresh boiling water to dissolve sugar. Add lemon juice and whiskey, stir, and top with more boiling water. Garnish with a lemon wheel or peel studded with cloves.
garnish: Lemon wheel or peel studded with cloves
notes: The ultimate cozy warm drink—whiskey, sugar, lemon and hot water. Great for cold evenings. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

name: Boston Sour
ingredients: ½ oz egg white (optional for foam)
instructions: Dry-shake (without ice) the whiskey, lemon juice, simple syrup and egg white (if using) for 15 s; then add ice and shake again until well-chilled. Strain into a coupe or rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist or cherry.
notes: Essentially a whiskey sour with an egg-white foam top—smooth, tart, and elegant. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

name: Fancy Free
instructions: Stir bourbon, maraschino liqueur, and bitters with ice until chilled, then strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish with an orange twist.
notes: A simple, spirit-forward Old Fashioned variation that swaps sugar for maraschino liqueur, adding subtle sweetness and cherry-almond depth.

name: Bourbon Smash
instructions: Muddle the lemon wedges in simple syrup. Add bourbon, mint leaves and ice, shake until chilled. Double-strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice and garnish with a mint sprig.
notes: A refreshing 19th-century style cocktail: bourbon meets muddled lemon and mint for a drink that's vivid, crisp and minty. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

name: Rusty Nail
instructions: Add Scotch and Drambuie to a rocks glass with ice and stir gently until chilled. Garnish with a lemon twist.
notes: A smooth, spirit-forward classic—Scotch softened and sweetened by the honey-herbal character of Drambuie.

name: Mint Julep
instructions: Gently muddle mint with simple syrup in a julep cup. Add bourbon and pack tightly with crushed ice. Stir until the cup frosts, then top with more crushed ice. Garnish with a large mint bouquet.
notes: A Kentucky Derby classic—icy, aromatic, and mint-forward with a smooth bourbon backbone.

name: Moscow Mule
instructions: Fill a copper mug or highball glass with ice, add vodka and lime juice, top with chilled ginger beer, stir gently, and garnish with a lime wheel.
notes: Simple, crisp and spicy — vodka meets ginger beer and lime in a refreshing long-drink classic. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/moscow-mule-cocktail-recipe/) )

name: Daiquiri
instructions: Add rum, lime juice and demerara syrup into a shaker with ice. Shake until well-chilled and strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lime twist.
notes: A simple, elegant Cuban classic — rum, lime and sugar in perfect balance. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/daiquiri/) )

name: Daiquiri
instructions: Add rum, lime juice and demerara syrup into a shaker with ice. Shake until well-chilled and strain into a chilled coupe glass. Garnish with a lime twist.
notes: A simple, elegant Cuban classic — rum, lime and sugar in perfect balance. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/daiquiri/) )

name: Amaretto Sour
instructions: Dry-shake all ingredients (without ice) to emulsify the egg white; then add ice and shake again until well-chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with a lemon twist and two brandied cherries.
notes: A modern reinvention of the Amaretto Sour — nutty almond-liqueur meets fresh citrus, egg white foam and a precision bourbon float for depth. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/amaretto-sour/) )

name: Gimlet
instructions: Add gin, lime juice and simple syrup into a shaker with ice. Shake until well-chilled, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass (or rocks glass). Garnish with a lime wheel.
notes: A classic sour-style cocktail: gin meets lime and sugar in a crisp, tart serve — rooted in naval history and refined for modern tastes. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/gimlet/) )

name: South Side
instructions: Gently muddle the mint leaves with the lemon juice in a shaker. Add gin, simple syrup and ice, then shake until well-chilled. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a mint sprig.
notes: Bright, minty and crisp — a refreshing twist on the sour template with gin and citrus. Origins trace back to early 1900s speakeasy or club scenes. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/south-side/) )

name: Paloma
instructions: Add tequila, lime juice and a pinch of salt into a highball glass filled with ice, top with grapefruit soda, stir gently, and garnish with a lime wheel.
notes: Mexico’s national drink — light, fizzy and citrus-bright. A tequila base, fresh lime and grapefruit soda make this an easy crowd-pleaser. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/paloma/) )

name: Cuba Libre
ingredients: Juice of ¼ lime (and lime wedge)
instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice, add rum and lime juice, drop in the spent lime peel/wedge, top with cola and stir gently. Garnish with a lime wheel.
notes: A long-drink classic from early 1900s Havana — rum, cola and fresh lime juice make this simple yet historic cocktail. ([liquor.com](https://www.liquor.com/recipes/cuba-libre/) )

name: Gin and Tonic
instructions: Fill a highball glass with ice, add gin, top with chilled tonic water, and gently stir. Garnish with a lime wedge.
notes: Crisp, bubbly and refreshing — the classic highball where good tonic and plenty of ice make all the difference.

name: Lemon Drop
instructions: Coat the rim of a chilled cocktail glass with sugar. Add vodka, triple sec, lemon juice and simple syrup into a shaker with ice; shake until well-chilled and strain into the prepared glass.
notes: Bright, citrusy and sweet-tart — a modern classic often served with a sugar-rimmed glass. Invented in the 1970s. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

name: Flip
ingredients: 2 oz spirit of choice (rum, whiskey, brandy or port)
instructions: Add the spirit, whole egg and simple syrup into a shaker. Dry-shake (without ice) to emulsify, then add ice and shake again until well-chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe or small wine glass. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg.
notes: A historic style of cocktail dating back to the 1600s — rich, creamy and warming. Made with a whole egg and nearly any base spirit.

name: White Russian
instructions: Add vodka and coffee liqueur to a rocks glass filled with ice. Gently float or pour the heavy cream over the top and stir lightly if desired.
notes: Rich, creamy, and smooth — the classic coffee-liqueur cocktail popularized by *The Big Lebowski*.

name: Negroni Sour
instructions: Dry shake all ingredients (without ice) to emulsify the egg white; then add ice and shake again until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist.
notes: A riff on the Negroni where citrus, egg white and amaro bring a sour‐cocktail texture to the bittersweet original.
